questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for generalized fatigue and mild shortness of breath on exertion for 3 months. He has a history of recurrent patellar dislocations. He is at the 99th percentile for height and at the 30th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 140/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scoliosis, a protruding breast bone, thin extremities, and flat feet. Ocular examination shows bilateral upward displacement of the lenses. A grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 is the pathological closure of the pulmonic valve before the aortic valve. Instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 with inspiration, S2 will instead split with expiration. Conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block, may cause paradoxical splitting of S2. However, AR is unlikely to be the sole cause of a paradoxical splitting of S2.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is not associated with AR. Instead, it is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or tension pneumothorax, and is sometimes observed in asthma and pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is a delayed pulse with a low amplitude that is not associated with AR. Instead, it is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, who typically present with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur and, in more severe aortic stenosis, with angina, syncope, or heart failure.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 is not associated with AR; it is most commonly a result of an atrial septal defect. The second heart sound arises from the sequential closing of the aortic valve and the pulmonic valve. Inspiration increases right ventricular preload, resulting in a delay in pulmonary valve closure, which produces a physiological splitting of S2. Atrial septal defects produce a left-to-right shunt, increasing right atrial and right ventricular volume and forcing the pulmonic valve to close later regardless of breath.
Image Description:

A fixed split does not change with respiration and tends to be wide (i.e., the split is also audible during expiration). It may occur in atrial septal defect or severe right ventricular failure.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

E) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with AR. On palpation of a peripheral artery, such as the radial artery, the clinician will feel rapid engorgement of the artery followed by a significant, prompt collapse of the vessel. This is due to the incompetent aortic valve failing to maintain adequate diastolic pressure in the arterial system, which also causes a widened pulse pressure. Other findings of AR include pulse synchronous head nodding (de Musset's sign) and, occasionally, a rumbling, low-pitched mid-diastolic murmur (Austin Flint murmur) that is caused by the regurgitant blood striking the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, leading to premature closure of the mitral leaflets.

Patients with Marfan syndrome often have aortic disease (e.g., aortic regurgitation) as a consequence of cystic medial degeneration.

F) INCORRECT:

Radio-femoral pulse delay is caused by aortic coarctation. Physiologically, pulses rise simultaneously in the radial and femoral arteries. However, due to the restricted blood flow through the narrowed aorta, the femoral pulse will rise later than the radial pulse. AR does not cause radio-femoral pulse delay.
questions.hint: This teenager with tall stature, scoliosis, pectus deformity, thin extremities, and upward displacement of the lenses likely has Marfan syndrome. The presence of an early diastolic murmur and widened pulse pressure indicate aortic regurgitation (AR).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, he has noticed progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking his dog. He also becomes short of breath when lying in bed at night. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is heard best along the left sternal border. There is an S3 gallop. Carotid pulses are strong. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. Although MS produces a decrescendo diastolic murmur, it is usually slightly delayed after S2 and would be heard best along the left midclavicular line (at third left intercostal space), not the left sternal border. A prominent S1 and/or an opening snap of the mitral valve after S2 may also be present. Furthermore, since MS restricts left ventricular blood flow, left ventricular preload is decreased, such that carotid pulses would be diminished and an S3 would not be present.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, mitral regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the apex (5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line), not a diastolic murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

While very rare, tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can cause signs of right-sided heart failure (lower extremity edema, hepatomegaly), but not signs of left-sided heart failure (dyspnea, orthopnea). Furthermore, TR produces a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border, not a diastolic murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

D) CORRECT:

An early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation (AR). Regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) causes widened pulse pressure with a decreased diastolic blood pressure. To maintain an adequate cardiac output despite regurgitation, initially, there is a compensatory increase in stroke volume. Over time, the increased LV end-diastolic volume leads to LV enlargement and eccentric myocardial hypertrophy. Patients may be asymptomatic for decades despite progressive LV dilation. In chronic AR, this compensatory response results in left ventricular dysfunction, and patients develop signs and symptoms of left heart failure (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, S3 gallop). The diagnosis of AR should be confirmed with transthoracic echocardiography.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip) increase the intensity of the associated murmur as a result of the enlargement of regurgitation volume across the valve.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse can cause fatigue and dyspnea on exertion but is asymptomatic in most patients. Furthermore, it causes a high-frequency midsystolic click that is heard best in the mitral region. This patient has a diastolic murmur, which is not consistent with mitral valve prolapse.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

F) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, it commonly causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, not a decrescendo diastolic murmur. Furthermore, AS will more likely cause an S4 from a stiff myocardium due to left ventricular hypertrophy, rather than an S3. Carotid pulses tend to be diminished and delayed, not prominent.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur with an ejection click

In aortic stenosis, there is usually radiation into the carotids.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur would become louder with handgrip.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of palpitations and mild dyspnea for the last 2 hours. He has had similar episodes in the past that resolved within 20 minutes, but they have been worsening since he started training for his first marathon 1 month ago. Ten years ago, he was treated for streptococcal pharyngitis with a 10-day course of penicillin. His maternal uncle passed away unexpectedly from a heart condition at age 40. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/60 mm Hg. On examination, there is a decrescendo early diastolic murmur heard best along the left sternal border. His head slightly bobs about every second. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valve detachment is a complication of aortic dissection if the aortic valve is involved, leading to AR. While this young patient does have signs of AR, he does not have any risk factors for the development of an aortic dissection in a young person, including connective tissue diseases (especially Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or Marfan syndrome) or a deceleration injury in a motor vehicle accident.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcific aortic valve disease is the most common cause of AR in older patients. In young patients, a different finding is more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Asymmetric septal hypertrophy is not associated with AR but is the underlying pathology of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). It leads to left ventricular outflow obstruction in young patients and would present with exertional syncope and chest pain. The murmur heard in HCM is a systolic ejection murmur (crescendo-decrescendo) that increases with the Valsalva maneuver and standing, unlike this patient's diastolic murmur. It also does not cause a widened pulse pressure nor de Musset sign.

D) INCORRECT:

Antistreptolysin O titers are used to confirm a group A streptococcal (GAS) infection and are especially useful when acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is suspected. Although ARF can manifest with AR, ARF usually occurs within 1–5 weeks of acute streptococcal infection. Moreover, this patient's streptococcal pharyngitis was adequately treated, making rheumatic heart disease very unlikely. Finally, even in patients with rheumatic heart disease, antistreptolysin O titers are unlikely to remain positive 10 years after infection.

Rheumatic heart disease is the most common cause of AR in lower-income countries.

E) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration is the most common underlying pathology in mitral valve prolapse (MVP). MVP is also seen in younger patients, especially in those with connective tissue diseases such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or Marfan syndrome. However, this patient has a diastolic murmur and clinical signs consistent with AR and not MVP (rather heard as a systolic murmur with clicking). Although myxomatous degeneration is occasionally associated with AR, this patient has no clinical signs of a connective tissue disease like hypermobility, hyperelasticity (Ehlers-Danlos), or tall stature/long limbs (Marfan), and another underlying cause is more likely.

F) CORRECT:

Congenital bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) is the most common cause of AR in young adults in high-income countries. Patients with congenital BAV can present with features of aortic stenosis and/or features of regurgitation. The clinical manifestations of congenital BAV vary depending on the presence of associated abnormalities (e.g., aortic root dilation) and left ventricular function. Aortic regurgitation often occurs due to underlying leaflet abnormalities (e.g., prolapse) and/or valvular apparatus dilation.

G) INCORRECT:

Valve vegetations from infectious endocarditis (IE) are a common cause of AR (especially in developing countries), as the vegetations prevent the valve from creating a proper seal to prevent backflow during diastole. This patient lacks constitutional symptoms, such as fever and chills, tachycardia, and malaise that would make IE likely. Furthermore, the patient lacks common extracardiac manifestations in left-sided IE, such as splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and/or Roth spots.
questions.hint: This patient's decrescendo early diastolic murmur heard best along the left sternal border, widened pulse pressure (> 30–40 mm Hg), and head nodding in synchrony with his pulse (de Musset sign) indicate aortic regurgitation (AR). Palpitations and symptoms of left heart failure (e.g., exertional dyspnea) are common presenting symptoms.

questions.text:
An otherwise healthy 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of palpitations. He says that he can feel his heartbeat in his chest all the time. For the past 3 weeks, he has had shortness of breath on exertion. He has not had chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. He emigrated from Nepal at the age of 25 years. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 145/56 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Although this patient presents with both dyspnea and palpitations, he lacks the characteristic holosystolic murmur of MR (best heard at the cardiac apex; left 5th intercostal space). In contrast, this patient has a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, his lungs are clear to auscultation, which makes pulmonary venous congestion unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis (PS) is usually a congenital heart defect. Acquired PS is rare but can occur in patients with carcinoid syndrome or rheumatic heart disease. It typically manifests with features of right-sided heart failure rather than the dyspnea and palpitations seen in this patient. The typical murmur of PS is an ejection systolic murmur, which is heard best parasternally at the left 2nd intercostal space, often with a widely split S2. This patient's diastolic murmur rules out PS as a possible diagnosis.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

C) CORRECT:

The patient has a diastolic murmur, which shortens the list of differentials here to mitral stenosis (MS), aortic regurgitation (AR), tricuspid stenosis (TS), and pulmonary regurgitation (PR). Let's have a look at the location of the murmur: it is best heard at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). This location makes MS unlikely (usually best heard at the apex) but is consistent with a murmur caused by AR due to valvular disease. Now, here comes the tricky part. In this patient, TS and PR cannot be excluded by cardiac auscultation because the left sternal border is also the location at which murmurs due to TS and PR are best heard. However, subtle details make AR more likely. PR can occur in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease (cor pulmonale) or chronic congestive heart failure, but this patient has no clinical features to suggest either of these etiologies. Isolated TS or PR are extremely rare (usually caused by endocarditis in intravenous drug users, or by congenital heart defects), and manifest with features of right heart failure, which are not seen here. This patient's history of emigration from Nepal increases the likelihood that the underlying etiology of valvular heart disease is rheumatic heart disease, which most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves. In patients with AR, a widened pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.

Other common causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve (most common cause of AR in high-income countries) and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root diseases is heard best over the right upper sternal border.

Timing the murmur against the carotid pulse is an important skill to master; if you are finding it difficult to time the murmur, try listening to the murmur again between 10 and 20 seconds using a slow playback speed and gradually increase the playback speed until you are proficient in timing the murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is a rare valvular abnormality that is usually asymptomatic. Right-sided valvular heart diseases are more common in individuals with a history of IV drug use, which this patient does not have. Chronic and/or severe TR manifests with features of right-sided heart failure but usually not with dyspnea or palpitations. Furthermore, TR causes a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border rather than a diastolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

The characteristic triad of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS) is exertional dyspnea, stable angina, and exertional dizziness/syncope caused by left ventricular outflow obstruction. AS causes weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus) and low/narrow pulse pressure, in contrast to this patient's findings. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotids.

F) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations if atrial fibrillation develops. Although the murmur that is characteristic of MS also occurs during diastole, it is most often a mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur preceded by an opening snap and is heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient has an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that is associated with a widened pulse pressure, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making another diagnosis more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can present with palpitations and exertional dyspnea. Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is one of the most common valvular abnormalities in the US, especially in young women. However, a widened pulse pressure is not common in MVP. Typical cardiac auscultatory findings of MVP would include a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the cardiac apex (left midclavicular line of the 5th intercostal space).
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.
questions.hint: The peak of the carotid pulse upstroke occurs immediately after S1. In this patient, there is a blowing, decrescendo murmur that is heard shortly after the carotid pulse upstroke, which is consistent with a diastolic timing. With early diastolic murmurs, the S2 cannot be distinguished from the murmur on auscultation, as is the case here.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated to the United States 35 years ago from India. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

D) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation. Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of aortic regurgitation in resource-limited countries.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of chills and worsening shortness of breath. He has no history of serious illness and does not use illicit drugs. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/60 mm Hg. There is no jugular venous distention. Examination of the extremities shows several nontender, nonblanching, erythematous macules on the palms and soles and painful nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes. Coarse crackles are heard over both lungs. Cardiac examination is shown. Results of initial blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings?
Video
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation. This patient's murmur is loudest at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). The murmur's characteristics and location make aortic regurgitation (AR) due to valvular disease the most likely diagnosis. Other causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve, rheumatic fever, and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root disease is heard best over the right upper sternal border (aortic area). In patients with AR, a high pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure but would result in low pulse pressure. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space (aortic area) with radiation to the carotids. Furthermore, IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation rather than valvular stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) can cause left heart failure and is a risk factor for as well as a complication of IE. However, a high pulse pressure is not caused by MVP. Typical cardiac auscultatory findings in MVP would include a midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the cardiac apex (left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line).
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) is the most common valvular disease associated with IE and can manifest with left heart failure. However, MR manifests with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex (left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line) and does not cause a high pulse pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

The murmur of pulmonary stenosis (PS) is heard best parasternally at the left 2nd intercostal space but this condition would manifest with features of right heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention) and the typical murmur of PS is an ejection systolic murmur, often with a widely split S2. Moreover, PS is usually a congenital heart defect. Acquired PS is rare and occurs in patients with carcinoid syndrome or rheumatic heart disease. IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation rather than valvular stenosis.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

F) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can be caused by IE and the murmur of TR is loudest parasternally at the left 4th intercostal space. However, TR due to IE occurs in patients with a history of intravenous drug use and would manifest with features of right heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention). Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and pulmonary edema would not be expected with right-sided IE. Moreover, the typical murmur of TR is a holosystolic murmur.
questions.hint: The presence of Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and features of left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema) indicate left-sided infective endocarditis (IE). The sound that coincides with the upstroke of carotid pulsation is S1. There is a murmur that is heard shortly after the carotid pulse, which is consistent with diastolic timing. With a decrescendo early diastolic murmur, S2 cannot be distinguished from the murmur on auscultation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of palpitations and shortness of breath on exertion. He has no history of serious illness. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/40 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a murmur along the left sternal border. A phonocardiogram of the murmur is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation causes an increase in left ventricular end-diastolic volume, as the left ventricle receives blood from both the left atrium and the regurgitant aorta. This results in hyperdynamic circulation and clinically manifests with palpitations and a widened pulse pressure, as seen in this patient. Patients with chronic AR can be asymptomatic for decades before developing symptoms of left heart failure. The recent exertional dyspnea in this patient indicates the onset of left heart failure, as the left ventricle is unable to maintain adequate cardiac output during exertion.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular wall compliance is increased in chronic aortic regurgitation because the left ventricle gradually enlarges and remodels due to the intermittent reversal of blood flow. Eccentric hypertrophy causes the left ventricle to become larger and develop a comparatively thin, more compliant wall.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased left ventricular wall stress is seen in conditions with decreased ventricular pressure, e.g., hypovolemic shock. This patient, however, presents with aortic regurgitation, which causes increased left ventricular wall stress due to intermittent blood flow reversal.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is seen in settings of distributive shock, e.g., septic shock. This patient, however, presents with aortic regurgitation, which causes increased left atrial pressure and consequently raised pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. PCWP can also be normal in compensated aortic regurgitation but would not be decreased.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased left ventricular afterload is seen in conditions involving peripheral vasodilation (e.g., due to medication use or distributive shock). This patient, however, presents with aortic regurgitation, which usually causes increased afterload because intermittent blood flow reversal increases systolic stress.

F) INCORRECT:

Right ventricular oxygen saturation would be increased in an atrial septal defect. While an atrial septal defect can also manifest with a murmur and exertional dyspnea, it is typically characterized by a widely fixed S2, which is not seen here. In addition, an atrial septal defect would not manifest with increased pulse pressure.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and decrescendo diastolic murmur along the left sternal border are consistent with aortic regurgitation, which is likely due to a congenital bicuspid aortic valve (given his age and the absence of other risk factors, e.g., intravenous drug use, Marfan syndrome, history of rheumatic fever).

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of fever, chills, and dyspnea. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F) and pulse is 90/min. Cardiac examination shows a murmur. In addition to other measures, cardiac catheterization is performed. A graph showing the results of the catheterization is shown. This patient most likely has which of the following valvular heart defects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) is often accompanied by a rumbling, delayed diastolic murmur that is characterized by an opening snap. In contrast to the findings in this patient, cardiac catheterization would reveal a left atrial pressure that is significantly higher than the left ventricular pressure during the ventricular filling phase (i.e., diastole). This increase in pressure occurs as the left atrium contracts to fill the left ventricle across the stenotic mitral valve.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) is often accompanied by a high-pitched, holosystolic murmur. The characteristic pressure tracing in MR is a rapid increase in left atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to the regurgitation of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium. However, cardiac catheterization in this patient does not show an increase in left atrial pressure during systole.

C) INCORRECT:

On cardiac catheterization, pulmonary regurgitation is associated with increased end-diastolic right ventricular pressure due to the increased backflow of blood across the regurgitant pulmonary valve during diastole. However, this graph shows pressure changes in the left rather than the right heart.

D) CORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is often a complication of infectious endocarditis, which can manifest with the fever, chills, and dyspnea. Valvular bacterial vegetations can cause destruction and incompetency of the aortic valve. In AR, regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) leads to higher end-diastolic volume and therefore higher preload and stroke volume, which increases aortic systolic pressure. Diastolic aortic pressure is classically decreased because of rapid return of blood to the LV through the incompetent aortic valve. Consequently, there would be an increase in pulse pressure, which can manifest with water hammer pulse and pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign).

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) is often accompanied by a harsh systolic murmur with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern. Cardiac catheterization in AS typically shows a peak ventricular pressure that is significantly higher than the peak aortic pressure. This finding is a result of the elevated ventricular pressure required to pump blood through the stenotic aortic valve before the return to normal systolic pressure in the aorta. However, cardiac catheterization in this patient shows a peak ventricular pressure that is identical to the peak aortic pressure.
questions.hint: The pressure-time graph shows low aortic diastolic pressure and high systolic pressure. This indicates elevated pulse pressure.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent palpitations over the past 2 months. He says that he was diagnosed with a minor heart defect during childhood but does not remember the details and has not had regular medical follow-up examinations since. Physical examination shows a heart murmur. Cardiac catheterization is performed and hemodynamic results show:



Oxygen saturation (%)
Pressure (mm Hg)



Right atrium
75
5


Right ventricle
75
25/4


Pulmonary trunk
75
22/15


Left atrium
99
12


Left ventricle
99
155/10


Ascending aorta
99
155/57



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can cause heart murmur (decrescendo diastolic murmur), palpitations, and normal oxygen saturation but it also increases left atrial pressure (N = 2–12 mm Hg) and decreases left ventricular diastolic pressure (N = 5–12 mm Hg) due to a decreased amount of blood reaching the left ventricle during diastole. Additionally, this patient's increased systolic pressures in the aorta and left ventricle are not consistent with mitral stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation can cause murmur (holosystolic murmur), palpitations, and normal oxygen saturation but mitral regurgitation increases left atrial pressure (N = 2–12 mm Hg), unlike the normal left atrial pressure seen here. Moreover, mitral regurgitation does not explain this patient's increased aortic pressure.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and cardiac catheterization readings are consistent with chronic aortic valve regurgitation (AR) in a compensated state. In AR, blood flows back from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) during diastole, decreasing aortic diastolic pressure (N = 60–90 mm Hg). The regurgitant blood mixes with blood flowing from the left atrium to fill the LV, increasing the left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV). This increase in LVEDV leads to an increase in preload and a subsequent increase in stroke volume (Frank-Starling mechanism). As a result of this process, systolic pressure is increased in both the aorta (N = 90–140 mm Hg) and the LV (N = 90–140 mm Hg). In chronic AR, eccentric hypertrophy in the LV increases LV compliance, which helps to maintain a normal LV diastolic pressure (N = 5–12 mm Hg) despite the increased LVEDV. Patients with acute AR in whom eccentric hypertrophy has not yet occurred, or patients with decompensated chronic AR in whom there is LV systolic failure, may experience increased LV diastolic pressure. In AR, cardiac chamber oxygen saturation, large vessel oxygen saturation, and right heart pressures remain normal.

This patient's underlying heart defect is most likely a bicuspid aortic valve, one of the most common causes of aortic insufficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) can cause heart murmur (holosystolic murmur) and palpitations. VSDs usually increase right ventricular pressure (N =15–30/1–7 mm Hg) and right ventricular oxygen saturation (N = 60–80%) due to the shunting of oxygen-rich blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, unlike the normal right ventricular pressure and oxygen saturation seen here.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis can cause heart murmur (crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur), palpitations, normal oxygen saturation, and increased left ventricular systolic pressure (due to higher ejection resistance). However, aortic systolic pressure in patients with aortic stenosis is decreased, not increased. Additionally, a decreased diastolic pressure in the aorta is inconsistent with aortic stenosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) can cause a heart murmur (systolic pulmonary ejection murmur) and palpitations. However, in ASD, pressures in the right atrium (N = 2–7 mm Hg), right ventricle (N =15–30/1–7 mm Hg), and pulmonary trunk (N = 15–30/4–12 mm Hg), and the oxygen saturation in the right side of the heart (N = 60–80%) would be increased as a result of a left-right shunt.
Image Description:

An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood
questions.hint: The patient has a widened pulse pressure in the ascending aorta.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes reports a new symptom of mild dyspnea when he walks two blocks.
His heart rate is 98 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 135/54 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 96% while he is breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is estimated at 8 cm. His point of maximal impulse is laterally displaced, and his rhythm is regular.
A diastolic decrescendo murmur is heard at the left sternal border and is graded 3 on a scale of 1 to 4. It becomes more apparent when the patient sits upright. He also has a low-pitched diastolic rumble best heard at the apex, with normal first and second heart sounds and no extra heart sounds. His lungs are clear to auscultation. He has no lower-extremity edema.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A low-pitched diastolic rumble at the apex, also known as an Austin Flint murmur, is generated when the regurgitant aortic jet is directed toward the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, causing premature closure of the leaflet. It is distinguishable from mitral stenosis by the absence of a loud first heart sound and an opening snap.

B) INCORRECT:

A physiological murmur that is related to high cardiac output is systolic (never diastolic).

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur along the left sternal border that becomes louder with the Valsalva maneuver.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonic insufficiency results in a high-pitched diastolic murmur at the sternal border but not a diastolic rumble at the apex.

E) CORRECT:

Chronic aortic regurgitation produces a decrescendo diastolic murmur, volume overload, and dilation of the left ventricle. It is also associated with an increased stroke volume and widened pulse pressure. A low-pitched diastolic rumble at the apex, also known as an Austin Flint murmur, is generated when the regurgitant aortic jet is directed toward the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, causing premature closure of the leaflet. It is distinguishable from mitral stenosis by the absence of a loud first heart sound and an opening snap.

Key learning point: A low-pitched diastolic rumble at the apex in a patient with a decrescendo diastolic murmur at the left sternal border is most consistent with a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presents to the ambulatory care clinic with progressive dyspnea on exertion. He first noticed the dyspnea 2 months ago. At that time, he was able to walk one mile per day, but now he can walk for only 2 blocks before experiencing shortness of breath. He has no known medical history but has not been seen in a health care setting in years. He smokes cigarettes and has a 45-pack-year history. He reports drinking 6 or more beers on weekends.
On physical examination, he is afebrile and has a blood pressure of 138/57 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing ambient air.
Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm with a diastolic murmur that extends through mid-diastole and is graded 2 on a scale of 1 to 4. No rub or gallop is detected. The point of maximal impulse is diffuse and laterally displaced. Jugular venous pressure is mildly elevated. Lung examination reveals faint crackles at the bases but no wheezes or rhonchi. The abdomen is mildly distended but soft. There is 1+ peripheral pitting edema bilaterally around the ankles. Bounding pulses are detectable bilaterally.
A complete blood count is within normal limits. An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm, normal axis, and no signs of ischemia.
Which one of the following diagnostic studies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ambulatory ECG monitoring is helpful when there is concern for intermittent arrhythmia as a cause of episodic dyspnea. In these cases, patients will typically describe palpitations or a “racing heart” (tachycardia).

B) INCORRECT:

Spirometry is the most appropriate study to establish a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Although this patient has an extensive history of cigarette smoking, his relatively rapid onset of symptoms and lack of wheezes or decreased breath sounds on physical examination do not support a COPD diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography would be reasonable if there were greater concerns for ischemia from the patient’s history, the electrocardiogram (ECG), or a stress test.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s findings of exertional dyspnea, diastolic murmur, and widened pulse pressure are all consistent with a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation. Chronic aortic regurgitation can be asymptomatic for decades. Patients with severe aortic regurgitation may present with exertional dyspnea, angina, or heart failure. The presence of a diastolic murmur strongly suggests aortic regurgitation; diagnosis is best established by a transthoracic echocardiogram.

Key learning point: In a patient with progressive shortness of breath, diastolic murmur, widened pulse pressure, and a normal electrocardiogram, the most appropriate diagnostic study is transthoracic echocardiography to assess for aortic regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography can be used to diagnose pulmonary embolism (PE). However, neither the tempo of this patient’s dyspnea (i.e., more subacute than one would expect) nor his cardiac murmur is consistent with PE. Signs and symptoms of PE can vary, but suggestive findings include asymmetric pedal edema, a right-sided third heart sound, and lungs that are clear on auscultation.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents to the ambulatory care clinic with a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion. At that time, he could walk one mile per day, but now he can walk for only 2 blocks before experiencing shortness of breath. He smokes cigarettes and has a 45-pack-year history. His pulse is 88/min and blood pressure is 138/57 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/4 diastolic murmur that extends through mid-diastole. No rub or gallop is detected. The point of maximal impulse is diffuse and laterally displaced. Jugular venous pressure is mildly elevated. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Bounding pulses are detectable bilaterally. An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm, normal axis, and no signs of ischemia. Which one of the following diagnostic studies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ambulatory ECG monitoring is helpful when there is concern for intermittent arrhythmia as a cause of episodic dyspnea. In these cases, patients will typically describe palpitations or a “racing heart” (tachycardia).

B) INCORRECT:

Spirometry is the most appropriate study to establish a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Although this patient has an extensive history of cigarette smoking, his relatively rapid onset of symptoms and lack of wheezes or decreased breath sounds on physical examination do not support a COPD diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography would be reasonable if there were greater concerns for ischemia from the patient’s history, the electrocardiogram (ECG), or a stress test.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s findings of exertional dyspnea, diastolic murmur, and widened pulse pressure are all consistent with a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation. Chronic aortic regurgitation can be asymptomatic for decades. Patients with severe aortic regurgitation may present with exertional dyspnea, angina, or heart failure. The presence of a diastolic murmur strongly suggests aortic regurgitation; diagnosis is best established by a transthoracic echocardiogram.

Key learning point: In a patient with progressive shortness of breath, diastolic murmur, widened pulse pressure, and a normal electrocardiogram, the most appropriate diagnostic study is transthoracic echocardiography to assess for aortic regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography can be used to diagnose pulmonary embolism (PE). However, neither the tempo of this patient’s dyspnea (i.e., more subacute than one would expect) nor his cardiac murmur is consistent with PE. Signs and symptoms of PE can vary, but suggestive findings include asymmetric pedal edema, a right-sided third heart sound, and lungs that are clear on auscultation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, high pulse pressure, and a mid-diastolic murmur which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation (AR).

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the office for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated to the United States 35 years ago from India. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

D) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of AR in developing countries.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office for decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, he has noticed progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking his dog. He also becomes short of breath when lying in bed at night. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is heard best along the left sternal border. There is an S3 gallop. Carotid pulses are strong. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. Although MS produces a decrescendo diastolic murmur, it is usually slightly delayed after S2 and would be heard best along the left midclavicular line (at third left intercostal space), not the left sternal border. A prominent S1 and/or an opening snap of the mitral valve after S2 may also be present. Furthermore, since MS restricts left ventricular blood flow, left ventricular preload is decreased, such that carotid pulses would be diminished and an S3 would not be present.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, mitral regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the apex (5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line), not a diastolic murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

While very rare, tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can cause signs of right-sided heart failure (lower extremity edema, hepatomegaly), but not signs of left-sided heart failure (dyspnea, orthopnea). Furthermore, TR produces a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border, not a diastolic murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

D) CORRECT:

An early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation (AR). Regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) causes widened pulse pressure with a decreased diastolic blood pressure. To maintain an adequate cardiac output despite regurgitation, initially, there is a compensatory increase in stroke volume. Over time, the increased LV end-diastolic volume leads to LV enlargement and eccentric myocardial hypertrophy. Patients may be asymptomatic for decades despite progressive LV dilation. In chronic AR, this compensatory response results in left ventricular dysfunction, and patients develop signs and symptoms of left heart failure (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, S3 gallop). The diagnosis of AR should be confirmed with transthoracic echocardiography.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip) increase the intensity of the associated murmur as a result of the enlargement of regurgitation volume across the valve.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation presents with a high-pitched, early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, widened pulse pressure, and can lead to left-sided heart failure symptoms and an S3 gallop.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, it commonly causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, not a decrescendo diastolic murmur. Furthermore, AS will more likely cause an S4 from a stiff myocardium due to left ventricular hypertrophy, rather than an S3. Carotid pulses tend to be diminished and delayed, not prominent.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur with an ejection click

In aortic stenosis, there is usually radiation into the carotids.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur would become louder with handgrip.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents with increasing shortness of breath and occasional palpitations for the past three months. He also reports throbbing headaches and sleeps on two pillows due to orthopnea. He has poorly controlled hypertension and denies fever or intravenous drug use. Physical examination shows bounding radial pulses and a diastolic murmur best heard in the left third intercostal space along the sternal border when leaning forward (see reports).

Blood pressure
160/52 mm Hg


Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly
ECG: Signs of left ventricular hypertrophy

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonic regurgitation produces a diastolic murmur best heard in the second intercostal space, often linked to pulmonary or right ventricular issues. The wide pulse pressure, bounding pulses, left ventricular hypertrophy, and cardiomegaly suggest left-sided volume overload, not pulmonic regurgitation. Poorly controlled hypertension also supports a left-sided cardiac process.

B) CORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation manifests with retrograde blood flow from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole due to an incompetent aortic valve. This results in a widened pulse pressure, as seen in the blood pressure reading of 160/52 mm Hg, and bounding peripheral pulses. The diastolic murmur, best heard at the left third intercostal space along the sternal border when leaning forward, is due to turbulent backflow. Chronic volume overload leads to left ventricular dilation and hypertrophy, evidenced by cardiomegaly on chest X-ray and left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG. These findings align with the pathophysiology of aortic regurgitation.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation is characterized by an early diastolic murmur at the left upper sternal border, cardiomegaly, and left ventricular hypertrophy due to volume overload.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis manifests with a systolic crescendo–decrescendo murmur at the right upper sternal border, unlike the diastolic murmur described. The wide pulse pressure and bounding pulses suggest a regurgitant process rather than stenosis. The murmur's location and accentuation when leaning forward further indicate aortic regurgitation, not stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation typically presents with a holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex radiating to the axilla, not a diastolic murmur. The wide pulse pressure and bounding pulses are not characteristic of mitral regurgitation. Although orthopnea can occur in both conditions, the described murmur and hemodynamic findings do not match mitral regurgitation.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath and occasional palpitations for 6 months. He has no history of chest pain or syncope. Cardiac auscultation reveals a soft, high-pitched sound immediately following S2 best heard along the left sternal border.

Blood pressure
150/60 mm Hg

Which additional finding is this patient most likely to exhibit?

choices.text: Mid-diastolic murmur with an opening snap at the apex
Holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex
Exaggerated drop in systolic pressure upon inspiration
Pistol-shot sound over the femoral arteries

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mid-diastolic murmur with an opening snap at the apex is characteristic of mitral stenosis, where the opening snap is due to the abrupt halting of stenotic mitral leaflets. The patient's wide pulse pressure and the sound immediately following S2 are more consistent with aortic regurgitation, not mitral stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur at the apex is associated with mitral regurgitation, where blood flows from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole. This murmur typically radiates toward the axilla. The patient's auscultatory finding of a soft, high-pitched sound immediately following S2 along the left sternal border and the wide pulse pressure are more indicative of aortic regurgitation rather than mitral regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

An exaggerated drop in systolic pressure upon inspiration, known as pulsus paradoxus, is associated with conditions like cardiac tamponade or severe obstructive airway disease. It involves an inspiratory increase in right ventricular filling that impairs left ventricular filling. The patient's presentation of a diastolic sound following S2 and wide pulse pressure aligns with aortic regurgitation, not pulsus paradoxus.

D) CORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation results in blood flowing back into the left ventricle during diastole, causing a decrease in diastolic pressure and an increase in stroke volume, leading to elevated systolic pressure. This creates a wide pulse pressure, as seen in the blood pressure reading of 150/60 mm Hg. The wide pulse pressure leads to bounding arterial pulses and can produce high-frequency sounds, known as pistol-shot sounds, over peripheral arteries like the femoral arteries. These sounds reflect the turbulent, high-velocity flow and rapid pressure changes characteristic of significant aortic regurgitation.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation is characterized by a collapsing pulse, wide pulse pressure, early diastolic murmur, and signs such as Traube's sign (pistol-shot sound over femoral arteries).

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man presents with six months of progressive exercise intolerance and frequent palpitations, sometimes at rest. Examination reveals a high-pitched, blowing murmur throughout diastole along the left sternal edge, and a laterally displaced apical impulse. He has no peripheral edema.

Blood pressure
140/50 mm Hg

Which of the following best accounts for these cardiac findings?

choices.text: Impaired filling from a restrictive process leading to diastolic failure
Excessive diastolic inflow causing chronic volume overload of the left ventricle
Chronic pressure overload producing concentric ventricular hypertrophy
Elevated left atrial pressure from mitral valve obstruction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy involves reduced ventricular compliance, leading to diastolic dysfunction and elevated filling pressures. It often results in a small or non-dilated ventricle and systemic congestion, not a displaced apical impulse. The wide pulse pressure and diastolic murmur suggest regurgitant flow, not impaired filling.

B) CORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation involves retrograde blood flow from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole, leading to chronic volume overload. This results in eccentric hypertrophy and left ventricular dilation, manifesting as a laterally displaced apical impulse. The high-pitched, blowing diastolic murmur along the left sternal edge is due to turbulent regurgitant flow. The wide pulse pressure (140/50 mm Hg) reflects increased systolic ejection and rapid diastolic runoff. The augmented left ventricular volume and wall stress can cause palpitations.

Key learning point: A diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal edge and a displaced apex beat are indicative of aortic regurgitation, which causes volume overload and left ventricular enlargement.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic pressure overload, as seen in systemic hypertension or aortic stenosis, leads to concentric hypertrophy without significant chamber dilation. This does not cause a laterally displaced apical impulse or wide pulse pressure. The findings suggest volume overload, consistent with regurgitant lesions, not pressure overload.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis typically causes a mid-diastolic, low-pitched rumble at the apex with an opening snap, not a high-pitched, blowing diastolic murmur. It often leads to pulmonary congestion and peripheral edema, which are absent here. The laterally displaced apical impulse suggests left ventricular dilation from volume overload, not seen in isolated mitral stenosis.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea over the past six months, now associated with orthopnea. He has a 3-year history of moderate aortic regurgitation and controlled hypertension on lisinopril. Examination shows a bounding pulse, a high-pitched early diastolic murmur best heard along the left sternal border, and an S3 gallop. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrates severe aortic regurgitation, left ventricular dilation, and an ejection fraction of 45% (reference range > 55%). Serum B-type natriuretic peptide is elevated. Chest imaging shows no signs of acute pulmonary edema.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management to prevent further cardiac dysfunction?

choices.text: Surgical replacement of the aortic valve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Afterload reduction with ACE inhibitors can decrease regurgitant volume in aortic regurgitation. However, this patient already has severe aortic regurgitation, left ventricular dilation, and reduced ejection fraction, indicating advanced myocardial remodeling. The patient is on lisinopril, suggesting that further afterload reduction is unlikely to reverse the structural cardiac damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Periodic echocardiographic follow-up is suitable for asymptomatic or mild aortic regurgitation with preserved left ventricular function. This patient has significant symptoms, severe aortic regurgitation, left ventricular dilation, and reduced ejection fraction, indicating established cardiac dysfunction. Observation alone does not address the progression of heart failure.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic severe aortic regurgitation leads to left ventricular volume overload, causing dilation and eventual systolic dysfunction. This patient presents with symptoms of heart failure, such as exertional dyspnea and orthopnea, and echocardiography shows left ventricular dilation and reduced ejection fraction. Elevated serum B-type natriuretic peptide indicates increased myocardial stress. Surgical aortic valve replacement addresses the hemodynamic burden by eliminating regurgitant flow, preventing further ventricular dilation and dysfunction, and improving long-term cardiac function.

Key learning point: In patients with severe aortic regurgitation and reduced ejection fraction, surgical aortic valve replacement is the recommended treatment to improve symptoms and prevent further cardiac deterioration.

D) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter aortic valve intervention is mainly used for severe aortic stenosis, where calcification provides a stable landing zone. In aortic regurgitation, minimal calcification can lead to improper anchoring and residual regurgitation. Surgical intervention is preferred for severe aortic regurgitation with left ventricular dilation and reduced ejection fraction, especially in younger patients without surgical contraindications.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents with two months of exertional dyspnea and occasional palpitations. Pulses are bounding, and there is an increased pulse pressure. Heart sounds include a normal S1 and S2. On auscultation, a soft, blowing diastolic murmur is best heard along the left sternal border at the third intercostal space, becoming louder when he leans forward and fully exhales.

Blood pressure
140/60 mm Hg

Which valvular lesion is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis typically presents with a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border with radiation to the carotids. The bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure observed here are inconsistent with aortic stenosis, which usually results in a reduced stroke volume and delayed, weak carotid upstroke.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis is characterized by a diastolic rumbling murmur best heard at the cardiac apex, often in the left lateral decubitus position. The described murmur's location and quality, along with the presence of bounding pulses and increased pulse pressure, do not align with mitral stenosis.

C) CORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation manifests with a diastolic, decrescendo blowing murmur best heard along the left sternal border at the third intercostal space. This murmur results from retrograde blood flow from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole, leading to a rapid decline in diastolic aortic pressure. Consequently, patients exhibit a widened pulse pressure and bounding peripheral pulses. The murmur is accentuated when the patient leans forward and fully exhales, optimizing the acoustic window. These findings, along with the characteristic wide pulse pressure, are indicative of aortic regurgitation.

Key learning point: A diastolic murmur at the base of the heart that increases with leaning forward and expiration is characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a holosystolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex with radiation toward the axilla. The diastolic murmur described, along with wide pulse pressure and bounding pulses, suggests a significant diastolic runoff, which is not characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of palpitations. He reports feeling his heartbeat constantly in his chest. Over the past 3 weeks, he has developed shortness of breath on exertion. He denies chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. He emigrated from Nepal at age 25. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 36.5°C, pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 145/56 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a blowing, decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left sternal border. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The characteristic triad of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS) is exertional dyspnea, stable angina, and exertional dizziness/syncope caused by left ventricular outflow obstruction. AS causes weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus) and low/narrow pulse pressure, in contrast to this patient's findings. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotids.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations if atrial fibrillation develops. Although the murmur that is characteristic of MS also occurs during diastole, it is most often a mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur preceded by an opening snap and is heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient has an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that is associated with a widened pulse pressure, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Although this patient presents with both dyspnea and palpitations, he lacks the characteristic holosystolic murmur of MR (best heard at the cardiac apex; left 5th intercostal space). In contrast, this patient has a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, his lungs are clear to auscultation, which makes pulmonary venous congestion unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is a rare valvular abnormality that is usually asymptomatic. Right-sided valvular heart diseases are more common in individuals with a history of IV drug use, which this patient does not have. Chronic and/or severe TR manifests with features of right-sided heart failure but usually not with dyspnea or palpitations. Furthermore, TR causes a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border rather than a diastolic murmur.

E) CORRECT:

The patient has a diastolic murmur, which shortens the list of differentials here to mitral stenosis (MS), aortic regurgitation (AR), tricuspid stenosis (TS), and pulmonary regurgitation (PR). Let's have a look at the location of the murmur: it is best heard at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). This location makes MS unlikely (usually best heard at the apex) but is consistent with a murmur caused by AR due to valvular disease. Now, here comes the tricky part. In this patient, TS and PR cannot be excluded by cardiac auscultation because the left sternal border is also the location at which murmurs due to TS and PR are best heard. However, subtle details make AR more likely. PR can occur in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease (cor pulmonale) or chronic congestive heart failure, but this patient has no clinical features to suggest either of these etiologies. Isolated TS or PR are extremely rare (usually caused by endocarditis in intravenous drug users, or by congenital heart defects), and manifest with features of right heart failure, which are not seen here. This patient's history of emigration from Nepal increases the likelihood that the underlying etiology of valvular heart disease is rheumatic heart disease, which most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves. In patients with AR, a widened pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.

Other common causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve (most common cause of AR in high-income countries) and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root diseases is heard best over the right upper sternal border.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation due to valvular disease manifests with a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border (Erb point).
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated from India 35 years ago. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. On examination, crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur, loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.

E) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.

Key learning point: A water hammer pulse—rapid, forceful arterial upstroke followed by quick collapse—is a classic physical finding in chronic aortic regurgitation due to increased stroke volume and rapid runoff into the left ventricle.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of AR in developing countries.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic because of decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, he has experienced progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking his dog and also reports shortness of breath when lying in bed at night. His temperature is 36.4°C, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, you hear a high-pitched, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is best heard along the left sternal border. An S3 gallop is present. Carotid pulses are strong. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation (AR). Regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) causes widened pulse pressure with a decreased diastolic blood pressure. To maintain an adequate cardiac output despite regurgitation, initially, there is a compensatory increase in stroke volume. Over time, the increased LV end-diastolic volume leads to LV enlargement and eccentric myocardial hypertrophy. Patients may be asymptomatic for decades despite progressive LV dilation. In chronic AR, this compensatory response results in left ventricular dysfunction, and patients develop signs and symptoms of left heart failure (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, S3 gallop). The diagnosis of AR should be confirmed with transthoracic echocardiography.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip) increase the intensity of the associated murmur as a result of the enlargement of regurgitation volume across the valve.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation presents with a high-pitched early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of left-sided heart failure.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, mitral regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the apex (5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line), not a diastolic murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea.
